thread.title: Wednesday's roundup: Mount Greylock, Pittsfield split league title after splitting season series
thread.title_full: Wednesday's roundup: Mount Greylock, Pittsfield split league title after splitting season series

title: Wednesday's roundup: Mount Greylock, Pittsfield split league title after splitting season series
text:
Posted: 10/14/2015 10:33:15 PM EDT Updated: 10/14/2015 10:40:25 PM EDT 
PITTSFIELD >> For the first time in school history, the Mount Greylock golf team won a Berkshire League crown. 
The Mounties earned a share of the Berkshire title this season by picking up a win against Pittsfield in both team's final match of the season, 170-172. 
Both teams finish at 13-2, with each picking up wins at the other's home course in the head-to-head matches this season. 
"It's a co-championship, but I'm not going to complain," Greylock coach Brian Gill said. "It's awesome. 
"In my opinion, Pittsfield is the best team in Berkshire County ... Things just went our way today." 
Matt Wiseman powered the Mounties with a 37. Pittsfield's Jake Driscoll shot a 40 to lead the Generals. Gill said the key to getting the win on Wednesday was the play of his seniors, Wiseman and Lilly Crolius (41). 
"Our two seniors absolutely carried us today," Gill said. "[Crolius] just played phenomenally well today." 
Both teams will now turn their sights to the Western Mass. tournament. 
———— Mount Greylock (170) — Matt Wiseman (37), Ben Gilooly (48), Lilly Crolius (41), Owen Jones (62), Kyle Alvarez (44), Bennett Zimmerman (56), Connor Daley (50). Pittsfield (172) — Kevin Quinto (43), Jake Driscoll (40), Thomas Symanski (45), Connor McDonough (52), Shane Tomacheck (45), Ricky Berrian (44). Birdies — Wiseman (No. 6), Crolius (No. 9). 
TACONIC 175, WAHCONAH 188 Advertisement 
The Taconic golf team left qualifying for the Western Mass. tournament until the very last day, but the Braves secured their passage to the postseason with a 175-188 win over Wahconah at Berkshire Hills Country Club on Wednesday. 
The Braves (8-8) were aided in their qualification bid by the bottom half of the lineup, with No. 5 golfer Brett Murphy taking home the medalist honors with a 41. 
"I'm pretty excited for the guys," Taconic coach Mike Hillman said. "We had to win yesterday and today to get in, and they knew that. Quite a bit of pressure on them, but they hung in there and put up some good numbers." 
Wahconah was led by Mike Shea and Andrew Beaudoin, with both golfers shooting a 47. 
Wahconah already qualified for the posteason, and the Warriros are 9-6 with one match to go on Saturday. 
———— Taconic (175) — Kyle Rochelo (53), Ross Omelenchuck (43), Mike Kays (43), Tim Curry (48), Brett Murphy (41), Connor Champoux (48). Wahconah (188) — Gage Frazier (54), Mike Shea (47), Jon Dos Santos (51), Colette Basiliere (46), Sam Clayton (48), Andrew Beaudoin (47). Birdies — Omelenchuck (No. 9), Kays (No. 6), Murphy (No. 5) 
DRURY 171, HOOSAC VALLEY 177 
The Drury golf team picked up a win over Hoosac Valley on Wednesday, 171-177. 
Nick Bator led the way for the Blue Devils, shooting a 40 to take medalist honors. Teammate Nick Boulger and Hoosac golfer Henry Sniezek both shot 42s on the day. 
"We just needed to shoot a little lower, the scores were a little higher for us than normal," Hoosac coach Jason Sniezek said. "If each kid could have shaved a few strokes off here and there, we could have pulled off the victory." 
Hoosac Valley is 6-9, while Drury improves to 5-10. 
———— Drury (171) — Nick Bator (40), Nick Boulger (42), Chad Lawrence (43), Ryan Baron (46), Reece Racette (61), Jude Collins (60). Hoosac Valley (177) — Jack Sniezek (43), Nate Lapine (46), Derek Alibozek (46), Henry Sniezek (42), Hayden Grimes (51), Luke Trombley (50). Birdies — Bator (No. 8), H. Sniezek (No. 3), Lawrence (No. 7). 
LEE 158, MONUMENT 184 
In Lee, Devyn Olds led Lee to a win over Monument Mountain. 
Olds shot a 37, making him the medalist. All of Lee's players shoot under 50. 
Dylan Buffoni led Monument with a 41. 
Lee improves to 11-3. 
——— Monument (184): Aaron Coons 43, Dylan Buffoni 41, Lexi Shumsky 52, Max Joyner 60, Max Jemelini 59, Dylan Tinker 48. Lee (158): Devyn Olds 37, Colin Finnegan 41, Thomas Fraser 40, Bryce Whalen 49, Hunter Roosa 40, David Belanger 45. Birdies — MM: Buffoni (No. 4), Tinker (No. 2). L: Olds (No. 5, 8), Finnegan (No. 4), Fraser (No. 7). 
LENOX 191, ST. JOE 195 
In Pittsfield, Lenox pulled out a close win over St. Joseph, ending the Crusaders season. 
St. Joe's Cody Tynan earned medalist honors shooting a 41 on the front nine of the Pontoosuc Lake Country Club, but Lenox's depth was too much to overcome. 
Kevin Coakley, Lucy Schwartz, and Noah Hunter, all shot in the 40s for the Millionaires. Andy Cella's 47 was the only other score below 50 for St. Joe. 
The Crusaders end their season at 5-9. 
"Tough day. Pretty chilly, tough conditions, and we just barely beat the darkness," St. Joe coach Fran Brilliant said. "Lenox had a little more depth, and that's what gave them the win." 
——— Lenox (191): Kevin Coakley 49, Ricky Anderson 55, Lucy Schwartz 46, Matthew Shields 53, Noah Hunter 46, John Fontaine 50. St. Joe (195): Andy Cella 47, Jake Felix 61, Michael Jingras 55, Connor Thurston 73, Condy Tynan 41, Brent Arseneau 52. Birdies — L: None. SJ: None. High School Boys Soccer 
ST. JOSEPH 3, HOOSAC VALLEY 0 
The St. Joseph boys soccer team used a hat trick from Mike Peplowski to blow past Hoosac Valley on Wednesday, 3-0, at Clapp Park. 
Peplowski scored one goal in the first half to get things started, converted a penalty for goal number two, then rounded out the scoring by converting a pass from Robert Patterson. 
Thien Nguyen set up Peplowski's first goal. 
In goal, Hoosac Valley's John Horton stopped two shots. Joey Maynard had eight saves to keep the cleansheet. 
St. Joe improves to 6-1-4. 
"In the first half, [Hoosac] had possession and opportunities without shooting on goal," St. Joe coach Juan Ramos said. "In the second half we played better, and didn't allow the ball to bounce around [on defense]. Late in the game they came at us and our goalkeeper had to make tremendous saves to keep them off the scoring sheet." 
————
